properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Brief intense snowfall is expected this evening. A strong front is making its way across the area. Associated with this front are flurries, heavy at times. Visibility will be suddenly reduced in heavy snow and blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T11:19:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T21:20:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1456782153.2019
Area: Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wet and windy weekend for Coastal BC Heavy rain and strong winds are in store for coastal communities of BC this weekend. An atmospheric river will take aim at northern Vancouver Island and the Central Coast beginning early Saturday morning delivering heavy rain and mild conditions until mid-day Sunday. The heaviest rainfall is expected along the west side of Vancouver Island and coastal communities of the Central Coast. The details remain to be finalized however; total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm are likely over these areas. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise upwards of 3000 metres for the South Coast and close to 2500 metres for the North Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. Mountainous regions further south including the Sunshine Coast, Howe Sound and the North Shore Mountains will also see significant rainfall, potentially exceeding the rainfall warning criteria of 50 mm in 24 hours. In addition to the heavy rain, strong winds will also accompany the moisture-laden system. Exposed coastal communities along West Vancouver Island, the Central and North Coasts will likely experience wind gusts in excess of 90km/h on Saturday morning. The public is encouraged to monitor potential rainfall and wind warnings from Environment and Climate Change Canada as well as potential high streamflow advisories or flood watches from the BC River Forecast Centre. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T13:18:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T21:19:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2486680001.2019
Area: North Vancouver Island, West Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions have developed and will intensify today. Wind gusts exceeding 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains with falling snow will produce near zero visibility in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate overnight as winds subside to 30 to 50 km/h. ### Road closures are likely. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T04:27:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T12:28:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1354406871.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls are expected this afternoon through tonight. A combination of lake effect flurries with a strong front passing over the area later today will result in periods of reduced visibility. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T06:36:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T16:10:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2751449267.2019
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 90 to 110 km/h. Locations: Hopedale, Postville and Makkovik. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday night. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday evening and become heavy, at times, on Saturday. Very strong northwesterly winds will develop on Saturday and cause near zero visibility in blowing snow. The snow is expected to taper off around midnight Saturday night and winds will begin to ease by Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-15T11:34:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T19:35:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1070265563.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-15T15:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-14T15:34:42-06:00, AA15DCE9-638E-4B48-EB28-DDB06028BF8E
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A brief but intense snow squall, associated with a fast moving cold front, will pass through the area between 5 and 6 pm this evening. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T03:02:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T22:06:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2240555683.2019
Area: Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls expected to begin this evening. A strong front is forecast to bring flurries over the area this evening. These flurries will result in brief periods of reduced visibility. Following the passage of this front, lake effect flurries are expected to develop along with local snow squalls. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T12:33:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T20:34:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3233719516.2019
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
